												First off, I do actually like the game. I really do. It is quite pleasing aesthetically, and has a great system in place that lets you play the game how you want.Problem is, how you want to play the game might not be very successful.It is of this gamer's opinion that a tower defense game should not be a puzzle game. There should not be a narrow band of builds that will actually grant victory among an immense number of combinations that could be played. With 15 different towers and 17 skills, picking just four of each can be difficult, yes, but it affords the player the ability to define how they want to go about defending their cores, and that's not even counting the perk points, which add another layer of depth and customization. This system by itself is fantastic, but the execution that makes use of it is rather poor.There is progression; not everything is available from the start. This progression, however, cuts off quite fast. Everything is unlocked at the point of hitting level 12, but the levels keep going, rather pointlessly. Perk points are gained differently, at a rate of 1 per completed map, and when you feel like you're not powerful enough to get past a particular map, there's a problem.Now, I can understand a TD needing some strategy; if one doesn't make you think about what you're doing, then it's probably not very good. SSTD, though, feels like it asks too much of strategy, putting the player on a very fine line between perfection and failure. I was doing fine with this game through the first few levels. I made a blunder here and there, and learned from what were clear mistakes (setting all Violators to attack the highest HP targets was a bad idea, for the record). There were some tougher levels that took me a couple attempts to figure out, but it felt okay. The challenge was fair. Then along came Works.Works is the map that I feel enforces an unfair level of difficulty and shows that the game really wants you to use a very specific setup to get through it. I have taken numerous attempts at it with different builds and have yet to even see the boss wave. I have beat my head against it long enough that I don't really care to continue. Maybe it's a fluke, maybe the rest aren't so bad after it, but I'm not going to put myself through the torture of trying to figure out the exact combination of towers and skills it takes to get through this map that seems to have too much of everything.Sure, I could just use the magic of Youtube and look for a setup that gets through it so I could continue, but that's not how I play; I would get no sense of accomplishment and may as well have used Cheat Engine to bypass the level in terms of enjoyment. When a game completely shuts down a player's ability to progress, without giving them an opportunity to either adequately learn what they're doing wrong or power up to overcome the challenge, then there is a significant problem that needs to be addressed.The game doesn't need to be easy; it just needs to cater to more than an elite 1% of builds. Don't tell the gamers how to play their game.

												Bland, rudimentary tower defense that looks and feels like a Flash game.Annoying controls that were designed for a touchscreen.Dull music and annoying sound effects. Thankfully you can switch the default "retro" music for an alternate soundtrack consisting of some tracks from Sanctum and Sanctum 2, and it's significantly better.The game isn't very well balanced. Some perks and special abilities barely do anything, and others are horribly overpowered. For instance, you have to unlock a perk that will let you place blocks at no cost, and the game pretty much expects you to use it from then on out or you won't have enough cash to place towers. Some perks will simply never be used because the others are so vital.The game also isn't very thrilling; you can only use a selection of 4 towers on any given map, and beating a wave only gives you enough cash to purchase maybe 1-3 new towers or to upgrade one. Upgrades are way too expensive, and if you consider that purchasing a second tower essentially doubles the effectiveness of the tower, then upgrading is almost never cost-effective unless you're playing endless mode and you ran out of room to place new towers. Plus, there isn't anything you can actually do to earn more cash than the level is scripted to give you aside from using some perks and making sure you kill all the enemies. The level ends after 10 rounds unless you're playing the endless mode, so you never really get the satisfaction of feeling like you've built a maze to maximum efficiency. Another problem with the game is with the abilities. Along with your 4 towers, you also get to bring 4 skills with you to every map (once you've ulocked them). Unfortunately they play too big of a part, and you'll find that winning a level relies mostly on babysitting the mobs with your mouse cursor and firing off your abilities as soon as they cool down every 10 seconds or so, and sometimes it feels as though the towers are barely doing anything to help. One of my most effective strategies involved using two mine-laying abilities and a cooldown-reducing perk, and stacking hundreds of mines all over the level. Not exactly the kind of gameplay I was expecting from a tower defense game.The game is glitchy as all hell and crashes a lot, especially after beating a level. Thankfully there are auto-saves and you can resume from the wave before the crash, but if this happens, you lose all the EXP you would have earned playing the level, so it's still annoying (at least early in the game when you still need EXP to unlock stuff).One thing I will give the game credit for is that it gives you the ability to individually customize what each tower shoots at within its range: the first or last enemy in line, or the enemy with highest or lowest HP. This makes a huge difference in your maze's performance and makes possible some very deep strategy. Another thing I thought was awesome is how the game gives you the option, upon beating a campaign level, to jump right into endless mode using your current build. These are some features I wish more TD games had.The levels themselves aren't too hard if you have everything unlocked and know how to adjust your strategies, but getting 100% can take anywhere from 5 hours to 30 hours depending on how fast you can get a stupid random event to happen.I give it a 4.5 / 10. It's just alright; you could do much worse. If you get this on sale for $0.99 or less, it's probably worth the purchase if you're into Tower Defense. Otherwise I wouldn't really recommend seeking it out.

Before the update that happened sometime this December, I was having decent fun with the game in the earlier levels - even though I thought they were a little too difficult for players who just started the game. I already thought the game was hard enough as it is, but for some reason the developers thought it would be a good idea to make the game even more unforgiving. I am now unable to go past a really early level in the game because of this.Super Sanctum TD has a great concept, with a variety of towers and powers you can utilize. I also liked being able to set up a maze for the monsters. Unfortunately, the balancing is currently out of whack so players will be struggling and wasting time trying to get past even the easiest of levels. If you think you have the patience, feel free to try it out but I doubt you'll go very far with the current version.

												Super Sanctum TD was a game I picked up for the combination of ridiculous sale price ($0.79) with trading cards. When I saw a game that looked to be similar to the original Sanctum games with the fast-paced FPS action taken out, I expected it to be a sloggy, boring grindfest - my standard opinion when it comes to the majority of tower defense games.Much to my surprise, Super Sanctum TD manages to dodge the most common gripes I have about the TD genre. Most levels have an open-ended "create-your-own-maze" approach, allowing for a lot of freedom and creativity in level solutions. SSTD also does away with long streaks of easy early-game snore-inducing levels - strong planning, resource management, and intelligent skill usage are all needed as soon as you complete the two training levels. The difficulty remains fairly consistent throughout, giving what seems like a paltry 14 stages a pretty beefy amount of playtime, as you'll likely need a few tries to figure out a suitable plan for much of the levels. On the other hand, if you find yourself breezing through the game, there's plenty of replay value in the form of an optional Hard difficulty, as well as infinite survival modes for every stage.SSTD isn't without its flaws, however - most glaringly is the game's fondness for crashing. Thankfully, the game does a fairly good job of autosaving, letting you continue right at the start of the wave you were left hanging on. The high difficulty I praised earlier can also be a bit of a double-edged sword - with a completely linear level structure, getting stuck on a stage will bring any semblance of progression to a screeching halt. An optional easy difficulty setting may have been a good idea for this reason.Super Sanctum TD may not be the most innovative game in the world, but what it does, it does very well. If you're a big fan of tower defense games, then this game is an absolute steal.

												Quick Summary: Unlike the previous Sanctum games, Super Sanctum TD is pure tower defense, so you’re not running around shooting the enemies, only your towers can attack. It’s also a much smaller game in terms of graphics and gameplay. I wouldn’t be surprised if someone told me Super Sanctum TD was built as a browser game.Also unlike the previous games, Super Sanctum TD has basically no storyline. The game is broken up into individual levels where you’re just trying to prevent the aliens from reaching the portal at the end of the level. The base layout of each level changes with each level and in most cases, you not only place towers, you also place the blocks upon which the towers are built. The aliens cannot pass your blocks so you can use them to create little mazes that give your towers more chances to blast the aliens. Since you’re not actually a player on the map you don’t need to worry about being attacked and the aliens do not attack your towers. Also unlike the previous Sanctum games, you have special skills/spells that you can activate during each map. The skills are generally area attack bombs or ways to slow down the alien advance, giving your towers more time to destroy them. These spells, along with the decent variety of towers available to you are the only way to block the aliens. It’s all strategy and planning with no real “skill” involved except for aiming the spells.Every time you beat a level, you earn a skill point that you can use on perks such as increased tower damage, increased area effect for spells, or decreased costs for blocks. You also gain experience as you play and unlock different spells. The skill points and levels are independent, so you can be level 30 and only have beaten 1 level but have all the skills unlocked. You can and must replay levels over and over for experience.Pros:+Uncomplicated game with a fast download since it’s so small.+You can be unskilled and still win if you look up strategies online since it’s your towers doing most of the work.Cons:-The game becomes super hard very quickly. I think I was only on the 3rd or 4th level before I got stuck and had to look online for help.-I said you could look up strategies online, but there actually isn’t much to be found except watching Youtube videos. This is probably due to how low profile the game is. Nobody wants to write a guide for a 100 megabyte game.Overall, the game is ok if you just want something to occupy your time for an hour or two at a time but it gets extremely frustrating if you’re trying to actually beat the game.

												Super Sanctum TD is the first tower defense game I've played all the way through. I've always enjoyed the genre, but I guess its never been able to keep my interest. However, Super Sanctum TD has opened a door for me, and beyond it is a genre I want to fully experience. The difficult thing about reviewing Super Sanctum TD is that I have no other experience to compare it to. That being said, I really, really enjoyed it. As a beginner to the genre I found the pacing to be on point, as the waves steadily grew in difficulty. I'll admit that I became stuck on a level for a few hours--trying and trying again to survive the onslaught. My mistake was thinking that it was your level (and in turn what items and weapons you've unlocked) that mattered when in reality it was a matter of strategy. Strategy plays a huge part in this genre, and when I realized that it wasn't my level but how I had set up my paths that was the problem, I beat the level with a perfect rating. Super Sanctum TD was teaching me that brains beats brawn in its playground. You have access to a wealth of different towers and perks to unlock as you progressively beat levels of the game. There are countless combinations to try out, and I have no doubt to each item's viability. There's also a lot of variety here, that lets you figure out your own playstyle. I for one leaned towards slowing enemies down while they got pummeled by towers that used AOE attacks. You also have access to a skill tree that grants bonuses to your towers and other areas. I haven't played much more after beating the campaign, so I haven't fully explored the tree. I did like the ability to regain all your points for redistribution whenever I wanted. It was helpful when I realized I had no idea what I was doing. In the end, all I can really say that I found Super Santcum TD an awesome experience. It certainly makes me want to play more of the genre. I definitely recommend this one for those times when you just want to sit down and play something for a few minutes without having to go too indepth.

												Quick Summary: Unlike the previous Sanctum games, Super Sanctum TD is pure tower defense, so you’re not running around shooting the enemies, only your towers can attack. It’s also a much smaller game in terms of graphics and gameplay. I wouldn’t be surprised if someone told me Super Sanctum TD was built as a browser game.Also unlike the previous games, Super Sanctum TD has basically no storyline. The game is broken up into individual levels where you’re just trying to prevent the aliens from reaching the portal at the end of the level. The base layout of each level changes with each level and in most cases, you not only place towers, you also place the blocks upon which the towers are built. The aliens cannot pass your blocks so you can use them to create little mazes that give your towers more chances to blast the aliens. Since you’re not actually a player on the map you don’t need to worry about being attacked and the aliens do not attack your towers. Also unlike the previous Sanctum games, you have special skills/spells that you can activate during each map. The skills are generally area attack bombs or ways to slow down the alien advance, giving your towers more time to destroy them. These spells, along with the decent variety of towers available to you are the only way to block the aliens. It’s all strategy and planning with no real “skill” involved except for aiming the spells.Every time you beat a level, you earn a skill point that you can use on perks such as increased tower damage, increased area effect for spells, or decreased costs for blocks. You also gain experience as you play and unlock different spells. The skill points and levels are independent, so you can be level 30 and only have beaten 1 level but have all the skills unlocked. You can and must replay levels over and over for experience.Pros:+Uncomplicated game with a fast download since it’s so small.+You can be unskilled and still win if you look up strategies online since it’s your towers doing most of the work.Cons:-The game becomes super hard very quickly. I think I was only on the 3rd or 4th level before I got stuck and had to look online for help.-I said you could look up strategies online, but there actually isn’t much to be found except watching Youtube videos. This is probably due to how low profile the game is. Nobody wants to write a guide for a 100 megabyte game.Overall, the game is ok if you just want something to occupy your time for an hour or two at a time but it gets extremely frustrating if you’re trying to actually beat the game.

												Super Sanctum TD is a low budget Sanctum series spin-off that lets you play a “retro” style 2D tower defense game instead of the usual Sanctum mix of tactical tower defense and engaging first-person shooting. If you’ve played either of the full-fledged Sanctum titles, you’ll immediately be familiar with the towers, the enemies, setting and soundtrack. However, Coffee Stain Studios may have pushed the “retro” thing too far. While the graphics and the soundtrack are pleasing, there’s no widescreen support and the sound effects are not only atrocious, but after a while they get pretty irritating. There’s really no reason for this game to be this low budget.The game plays like a typical 2D tower defense game with a few twists. There’s a decent number of towers although less than in the main series. The usual staples are here: gatling gun, laser towers, etc. You even get the slow and amp fields from the original Sanctum which for some reason didn’t appear in last year’s sequel. The aliens are back as well and there’s less of them as well. They range from big brutes, fast chargers, annoying flying ones and big bosses. The objective is to build mazes and place your towers in a way that’s most efficient in destroying as much aliens as quickly as possible before they get to the core.Keeping in line with the hands on approach from the main series, you also have a number of skills at your disposal which you can use during the alien onslaught. For example, you can set up mines, freeze a group of aliens, make them hover in the air for a limited amount of time, strike them with lightning, send them backwards for a bit and so on. All of these skills have varying cooldowns so you need to use them at the most opportune time.There’s not much content here. The single-player campaign spans 15 missions that you’ll be able to finish in under 10 hours on the normal setting. After that you can play each level on hard or in survival, but as far as game modes go, that’s about it. This is a low budget spin-off that never pretends to be anything else which is reflected in its price as well. The full price is only 3,99 euros, but it’s not unusual to see it slashed by 90%. And if you sell the trading cards, it’s likely that you’ll break even.In the end, Super Sanctum TD is a solid tower defense game that’s worth playing as it manages to deliver that tactical and addictive experience that such games aspire to offer. And even though it’s too low budget and extremely light on content, at that price you really can’t go wrong with this one.6 OUT OF 10 (ALRIGHT)

												TL;DR: This is a very simple, casual version of Sanctum without coop mode and without the 3D visuals.  The level of dificulty will scare some away almost immediately, but tower defense veterans may enjoy some of the subtle gameplay mechanics which allow for deep strategic thought.  The problem is this is not like other Sanctum games.Rest of the review:Sanctum was great, and I loved Sanctum 2.  I didn't get the Super Sanctum spin-off game until the 2014 winter sale, because I wasn't really fond enough of the 2D graphical style to part with much money for the game.  Well, the game finally dropped to an absurdly low price, so I took the bait and began playing.The first thing I noticed was that the combat was almost entirely about the towers and wall placement.  This is not Sanctum-like.  I was expecting a player character, but I got instead a god-like view with generic tower defense fare.  I was disappointed but did not let that sway me from giving the game a fair try.The tower options were very bare to begin with, but after a few completed levels, I unlocked a lot of towers.  You start with the gatling gun tower and eventually unlock more towers as you beat levels.  You can go back and replay levels using your new towers and new abilities in survival mode.The abilities are the closest thing you can get to player interaction with the game world, but I found that the best abilities were the ones you didn't actually get to use manually.  For example, you could have abilities which add to tower strength for a limited time when used, but you're better off unlocking the abilities which enhance towers indefinitely.  None of the upgrades are ever permanent, so there's little reason to replay the game from the beginning, but achievement hunters will enjoy the grind, I guess.The story is non-existent.Overall, I liked the game in a casual time-wasting way, but I cannot recommend it unless you're looking for something extremely simple, something intended for the most casual of gamers.  Considering the game's intended audience was Sanctum players, I doubt many will be satisfied with this game's more generic approach to tower defense.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												My feelings are very split on Super Sanctum TD. This is a true 100% turret defense game unlike its bigger TD/FPS hybrid siblings, which is mostly why I found myself addicted to it. However, it bears a number of the annoying signature characteristics found in the Sanctum series. And by that I mean the player is tasked with building the foundations for the turrets, and using these same foundations to shape a maze like path for enemies to corral. That on its own is fine, but the problem lies with being able to build an entire maze before the game starts and only having enough cash for 2 or 3 turrets that can't manage the first wave. This is the only turret defense game I've ever played where its not mostly passive building strategy, the player has to be very active between targeting and zapping enemies with manual weapons and sometimes even tear down and rebuild turrets further down range as the wave is still running. The other really annoying Sanctum characteristic in this game are the turrets themselves. Some of the turrets are junk. Their purpose is to be abondoned and never used again as soon as something better become available. The turrets are also unbalanced in that a number of them aren't worth leveling up since its not cost efficient nor as effective vs building more weak towers. I'm not quite sure they did things this wayAlso typical of the Sanctum series, SSTD is severely limiting. Out of the dozen or so turrets you can build, you're restricted to the 4 you choose on any map. I assume Coffee Stain Studios feels this adds to the game's strategy, but it doesn't. You can't exactly plan ahead for what you're going to need, so picking and choosing turrets tends to become trial and error. And speaking of bad strategy, the later levels force the player to pick specific perks. Of course I'm talking about the perk that has a chance of turning dead enemies into cash. Its not completely vital a perk to have, but oh boy does it sure help.In spite of everything I've said so far, Super Sanctum TD is an OK turret defense. Its no Defense Grid, nor is it meant to be. And for what it is, it's pretty damn fun. The other reason I'm giving it a positive review is the cheap price. On sale, you can buy it for spare change.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												Super Sanctum TD is a competently-designed, retro-flavored tower defense game that takes few risks and offers an appropriate degree of Fun. An endless horde of horrible space monstroids is pouring out of a weird invasion portal cabbage and it's up to you to place a variety of defensive turrets in the way to stop 'em! Along with your chain guns and flamethrowers and gauss rifles, you also have access to a variety of special abilities you can activate to blast those determined jerkfaces who manage to scrape their way past your gauntlet. As you play, you earn experience, unlocking new turrets and abilities. Level layout and wave composition are well-balanced, keeping up the challenge and often requiring multiple level attempts to achieve any sort of victory. And when all is said and done, you can go back for further challenges by attempting earlier levels on Hard Mode or Survival Mode.Unfortunately, this game comes from the same people who made Sanctum, which was a delightfully innovative tower defense / FPS hybrid. Dropping all the innovative aspects of the game just makes this seems like an attempt at cashing in on the franchise's name, which, y'know, isn't terribly exciting to the fans; the lore was never terribly compelling to begin with, and this entry contributes nothing new on that front. If you're an avid tower defense enthusiast, sure, the game isn't bad, but you'd be better off playing the other games in the series or trying out a more polished, well-developed tower defense game like Sol Survivor.

												On first glance, Super Sanctum TD seems like a very nice addition to the genre, but beware as the game is unbelievably hard even at normal difficulty forcing you to grind the same levels over and over until you get enough points to unlock new abilities/equipment. I'm not new to the TD genre but this game simply doesn't have mercy on its players; you have to optimize your maze layout to perfection and be very careful of selecting which towers to employ or there's no way you'll progress far beyond the training area. The 16-bit graphics look nice and serve their purpose, but the sound design is weak and rudimentary.Generally speaking, the game is way too hard and demands a far bigger commitment than I'm willing to make for what is basically a 2D flash TD game. Could've been much better if the devs weren't so hard-core. But I guess even the TD genre has to have its masochistic version of IWBTG.Score: 3/5

												This is a classical tower-defence game available for reasonal price. It's not some random "kill the runnning bugs" stuff you can find on free gamesites thousands of thousands times. Also, it's not some easy "i'll just put this and slap that" thoughtless building. The game is actually enough challenging to make the player think their choices. 												Super Sanctum TD is a short and sweet, simple flash-TD equivalent. I got this on sale for under $1, and it delivered everything that it promised.Tower balance is reasonable, though obviously positioning them properly is always crucial. The in-game skills/unlocks present several different ways to tackle most levels, be it ability-heavy or tower-heavy. I rather liked the 100% sell value unlock, as then I could move max upgraded towers around to kite slow moving bosses, or explore strategies like powering up one lightning tower until it 1-shots everything. The game has just enough cheese in its strategies to keep you amused, as you plow through all 14 levels.The achievements have good diversity - you'll unlock most of them just by playing. 1 or 2 are puzzle achievements, that require you to think about how to structure your maze and how to use tower synergies to unlock them. If you go for them, they force you to understand the game mechanics a little bit more, making you a better player.The normal and hardmode achievements are well thought out (play every level on hard and win; play every level on normal and don't lose health) - easy for any TD veteran to accomplish.There is one grindy achievement - kill 10,000 walkers - I groaned when I finished the game with only ~2700 of them defeated, as I thought it was going to take forever to get. It's actually not that bad... one playthrough of lvl 3 on survival with chargers and splash towers (like ACPs; take your pick) will get you most of the way there.Overall it was quite fun. I didn't notice any severe engine glitches that didn't work in my favour, but there were a few minor ones. Comboing time-rewind and teleport abilities has some odd/ineffective effects... Saving/loading is bugged, messing up tower stats and sell values, so be careful resuming a previous match. The game is also very likely to crash if you spam hundreds of mines at the end of your maze. I did have two crashes early on that were unrelated to cheese, but they happened on the first levels, which take only minutes to get through.Overall this TD feels like a 7/10 or 7.5/10. Priced right, with just enough polish and cheese. I enjoyed it.-BikeHelmet

Posted: October 25, 2016
												Super Sanctum TD (SS TD in short) developed by Coffee Stain Studios, the makers of Sanctum & Sanctum2. Released on the PC platform on  May 9 2013. It has an average user score of 7.3 on MetaCritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/super-sanctum-td). This came as a surprise but SS TD was released before Sanctum 2! If the dates are correct on MetaCritic, SS TD was released a week before Sanctum 2 went live on the PC. Who's up for a 2D solo, Tower Defense game set in a sci-fi theme battling hordes of aliens? Did I say that it was also "cute" ? No one? T.TSS TD inherits the entire Sanctum lore/concept. It is a solo game however - unlike Sanctum (or Sanctum 2) minus the FPS & heroes. This is just pure Tower Defense..with a little spell@skill casting moment. Any Sanctum player will recognize the art style of the towers/settings/aliens immediately. The most glaring difference is that, its a 2D miniature version of Sanctum. For me, that just looks super cute. That is, until they reach your core and you want to smash them to bits..*ahem* So let's get down to business. Controls: Controls are straight forward. Easy. You can't turn the map. So your focus will be on placement on towers, mazing & casting of skills. The game seems to be designed in a small screen fashion. I guess there's nothing else to see so they've restricted your view. Changing resolution doesn't really help enhance the visuals or Field of View of the game..unless you want to see even tinier aliens. The view was restrictive for me but it didn't hamper the game play experience. Yes, I've build towers and I've lost count which is level 1 or level 2 towers. Especially if you are going for endless wave OR if you are planning to build hordes of slow towers, you are going to face this issue. I wished the devs could have made a more visible indicator on the tower levels. I had to keep check on my towers - so thats micro management for you.Visuals:Like I mentioned earlier, everything looks like Sanctum. The aliens are tiny cute creatures running amok to your core but just because they look cute, it doesn't mean they are harmless. Things can get pretty nasty if you dont plan properly. eg: 70+ over tiny runners heading to your core.Game play:There is no story whatsoever in SS TD. You are straight thrown into the game to learn to build/maze/get to know your towers/aliens immediately. The objective of the game is simple. Protect your core from the aliens. You lose the game once your core has been damaged enough by the aliens. The end.If you defend the core without taking any damage(0 leak) - a perfect defense, then you will be rewarded with 3 stars. What does the star do? For achievement purpose. You are only given a max of 4 tower slot and 4 skill slot. So you have to choose from your collection of tower/skills and learn to build a combo@tactic around them. Planning is always crucial as each Map layout is different and so is the spawn of mobs. As you progress into the game, you gain experience points and you start unlocking higher tier towers/skills. And Yes, there will be bosses. Speed Runners, Flyers and the ones that eats up your towers. They are here. so are the mutators. >:-DMy Personnel Experience:In the early of the game, it seems pretty acceptable and fun to play. Until a certain level where you know you hit the limit and there's just isn't much you can do unless you start investing into other forms of tower/skills. By Mid game you would have realize that all you needed was the lighting tower family. So you ponder was the choice of tower selection a mere illusion? In some way yes. If you wanted an easier time, you'd pick certain towers over the others because it gets the job done better.By end game You've probably figured out which enemy was "weak" to which tower and what sort of tactic to deploy. You are probably aiming to get the 10k alien kills now.I am not into leaderboard but I am into achievements. I had a memorable time studying/exploring ways to complete certain maps/achievement. SS TD was fun and challenging however i'd say it lack certain aspect of the game.  The first is that it lack a drive. There is no story or motivation for players to complete the game. At some point, players them self can also lose motivation if they keep failing in at certain maps. getting stucked at some map without any form of aid is a painful experience. The second one is related to engagement. Aside from TD, there is nothing else to do. No mini games, no other game mechanics to keep you occupied when you are tired seeing the aliens. I was hoping that because this is 2d, solo offline TD game, the devs would try to introduce something new - something thats not FPS or co-op which has already been done in sanctum 1 & 2. If I may reference other games; For an example, Final Fantasy 7 on chocobos, Plant vs Zombie: plenty of mini games and zen garden. PvZ offers way more "gaming experience" and "value". The tower and alien description were very vague. You had to observe the battle to understand which unit takes more damage from X tower at X level or X tower seem to be better against X unit. Other than this, I'd say the game was fun & solid. Once I've beaten the game and obtained my 100% achievement, it is unlikely I will revisit SS TD again but for the highly competitive gamers, they will no doubt invest their time into perfecting their art of defense to get their name up in the legendary board of fame.My Summary:Super Sanctum TD as a whole, is a good solo, offline TD game. It would've been much better if it had an option for skirmish mode/co-op mode to retain its playerbase. A different game mechanic apart from the TD would be a welcome - It's a risky move for a simple 2D game but I seriously hope the devs will incorporate something new in their next solo TD product. So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Super Sanctum TD is a 6/10.
